turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Great, excellent. Before I go any further, can I confirm you name and your, um, age please?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh yes. Um Laura Parkinson. And uh I'm forty five.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Forty five. Alright Laura, well how can I help you this afternoon?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh yeah. So I have uh soreness in my fingers, my finger, like, the skin on my hands is kind of cracked.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. When, when did this all start?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, a couple of months ago. I got it three, four months ago.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNIN/> OK so it's been that long, has it? OK. And so you mentioned your <UNIN/>, is it the skin on your hand, mainly that's dry?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, I haven't noticed. I mean, I have dryness, like you know, in other parts, like my legs. But it's not, it's not very, it's not severe. It's just you know, I've always, you know, I don't hydrate very much. So

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah. Like it's very, it's very bad in my hands.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Can I ask why have you come to see me today? Uh is it because it's got worse recently, your symptoms?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah I mean, it's gotten to a point where, where it hurts a lot. And I can't really do my job. So, I thought I should probably get it checked out.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah, that sounds like a very sensible plan. Um, which part of your hands are affected, mainly?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh the palm. <UNSURE>I don't get</UNSURE>, yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, OK alright. Um, have you <UNIN/> any itchiness in your palms?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, it's itchy. Not all the time, but yeah, it does get itchy.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um um I don't, I mean, no I don't think so.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNIN/> you scratch yourself, you scratching yourself often, and bleeding?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, yeah I guess when I scratched it, yes it has bled sometimes but, yeah. Otherwise, it hasn't bled on its own.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Sorry, I'm <UNIN/> writing notes as we go along. Um, and you mentioned that skin is quite cracked as well. Is that right?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNIN/>, I know it's a long time ago, but do you remember how it all started? <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> what were you doing at the time when it all started? Is it anything you may have done, to bring your symptoms on?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, I mean I am a, I do work as a housekeeper. Um

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: And to be honest, I'm not always very good about wearing gloves. So that could be related. Um, I switched jobs, uh four months ago. Uh

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I've been working for, as a housekeeper for, for a while now, but um, that's the only thing I can think of.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah, I think that might be quite important actually. I think there's definitely, maybe a correlation between the two.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, fine. And so you mentioned something about having general dryness. Is that, you mentioned in your legs as well?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Is that, <UNIN/> is that something you've, you've had for a while now?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah. It's not really, it's not really major. Uh yeah it's just like literally grinding my legs.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. I'm just going to ask you some very brief yes or no questions, if that's OK. With your symptoms, have you, have you had any other symptoms, such as fever, or temperatures?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Any problem with your urine, or waterworks?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Otherwise you feel well, do you? And yourself, <UNIN/> your eating, drinking, your appetite is well-maintained?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, alright. Fine. Um, in terms of your past medical history, do you have any other conditions at all?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Do you know if that's type one or type two?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Not that I know of. No, I haven't been diagnosed.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: No, OK. Which medications do you take?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Metformin, OK. Do you have any allergies, either to any medications or in general?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Family history-wise, is there anything I should be aware of?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Diabetes as well. OK. Again, any skin problems?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh no, not that I know of.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Any history of asthma, or bowel problems?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Fine. In terms of social history, you mentioned that you work as a housekeeper. Um are you, you're not always very good at wearing gloves.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, you've recently changed jobs. Which <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> which kind of places do you work in? Is it mainly residential, or is it commercial?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: At a hotel. I have to do the whole thing like bedrooms, bathrooms, <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Do you think there might be a relationship between the two? Between the, kind of the products you're using, and your symptoms?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, I usually use those for bathrooms. But, yeah bedrooms and corridors not always.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Have your symptoms stopped you from doing any work? Have you had to take time off work recently?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, yeah like the past three days, I haven't been able to go to work.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Can I ask a couple questions? Do you smoke at all?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Do you drink much in the way of alcohol?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, a couple of pints a week.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> a week. OK so, very minimal, alcohol there. Um

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNIN/> have you tried anything for your symptoms? Have you tried anything over the counter? Any creams?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah. I tried uh E forty five.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, no it didn't really do anything.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I also tried an <UNIN/> antihistamine, antihistamine. Uh but it didn't

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, Mrs. Parkinson, so I think um, based on your story, I <UNIN/> I think you might have something called dermatitis or contact dermatitis. Which is very common in, particularly people in your in your in your field, who are using cleaning products, not using gloves. And sometimes you get a bit of reaction between the chemicals and your skin.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, so moving forward there's a couple of options. So firstly,  what we try and do is, you know, avoid the triggers. In your case, I strongly recommend that you wear gloves when cleaning at all times.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And in terms of helping your dryness and the cracking of your skin, um we can try some steroid creams to help with the inflammation.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: As well as some stronger emollients, um which you really need to kind of coat on, three four times a day, for the next couple of weeks, just to help with the moisturizing of your skin.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um if it still hasn't got better in about a week, two weeks time, I really need you to come back and see me again. And we can maybe think about other things we can give to you.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Great. Do you have any questions for me?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, where do I get the medicine from?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNIN/> I'll I'll I'll do a <UNIN/> prescription for you now, and send it over to your pharmacy.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK great. Yeah, uh so you said a couple of weeks, it should get better, right?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: I think <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> I think minimum couple of weeks. Uh ten days to fourteen days. Um and if it still hasn't got better, or indeed if it's getting worse, like if it's spreading, or dryness is getting worse, come back and see me sooner.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Great. Thank you Laura. Thank you.
